title: Abraham was a Hebrew, so how did he come to be born in an Arab region (Ur, modern day Iraq)? Was it because of the diaspora to Babylon? - Quora

response.answer_text: Most scholars nowadays think that Abraham is a metaphor for a migration or series of migration out of Ur, not one real person. Obviously if you’re committed to believing the Bible literally, you won’t accept that. But anyway, both in reality, and in a literal reading of the Bible, Abraham came long before the exile (“diaspora” is the wrong word) to Babylon. He was also before the Jewish race. “Hebrew” in that time just meant a “foreigner”. He was the first person to be called that, in the Tanakh (“Old Testament”). So he wasn’t really a “Jew” or “Israelite”. According to the Bible, he was the one with whom God made a covenant, and became the father of the Israelites. “Israel” was actually the name of his grandson, also called “Jacob”. So the foundation myth - or, if you will, the truth in the Bible - is that Abraham left the Ur of the Chaldeas, and travelled across to the Levant, where the “Promised Land” was. Then his great-grandson Joseph, and later Joseph’s brothers and father, migrated to Egypt, and there they developed into a race, as slaves under the Egyptians. Then after 300-something years they escaped, wandered around in the desert for 40 years, and slaughtered all the Canaanites and took the land which God had given them. Then there was the nation of Israel, for hundreds of years (well, split into two kingdoms) and then the Babylonian exile. That’s a brief overview of the story. So Abraham was well before the exile, and while he’s referred to as a “Hebrew”, he’s the father of the Jewish nation, which didn’t exist yet when he was born, because he was the patriarch of it. It is a strange sort of throwback that the story ends (kind of ) back in the same region where it started.

Because Abraham and his family were Amorites, and thus part of the group that entered Iraq and caused the downfall of the Sumerian dynasty - the original one. The Amorite tribes of which his father were a part, came to Iraq from Syria, and thus his brother Haran, is named after an Amorite-nfluenced town just to the north of modern Syria in the Anatolia peninsula. Hammurabi was an Amorite, for example, and probably Abram and his tribes left when the Hittites entered. And Abram was not a Hebrew - that term was not used until they entered the Canaanite area. He then became the father of the tribe that lived in the Levant and were called the Abiru, Hibiru, Ibiru, and other names by the Egyptians and others. They were wandering sheep drovers, sometimes called thieves as well by their neighbors, but I’m sure that part is just evil slander, right? I can give you some examples of what the Amorites introduced when they swarmed into Sumeria; interest on notes, where previously there was no such thing, an eye-for-an-eye type of justice, when previously only fines applied to most wrongdoings, and the idea that women, who held positions of power and were even goddesses in Sumerian history, were relegated to the level of dogs. Amen

Abraham was the first Hebrew (Genesis 14:13), the first of the lineage. His brother Nahor settled in Syria, and his son Bethuel had at least two children, Rebekah and Laban. Both Laban and his father Bethuel are referred to as “Syrian” (Gen. 25:20; 28:5; 31:20, 24). Considering that Abraham is the father of the modern-day “Arabs” (Ishmael), the ancient demographics of Ur aren’t really assessable. The diaspora wasn’t until centuries later as well. The lineage goes like this: Abraham, Isaac, Jacob/Israel; his twelve sons became the patriarchs/tribes of Israel. Forty years after God called them out of Egypt, they took possession of Canaan, then a few hundred years later wound up with wicked kings and got exported to Babylon/Persia. Egypt too, but that’s later. Abraham was a Hebrew because he was the first Hebrew, not because he was born into a Hebrew lineage.

A common misconception. Abraham was not a Hebrew, according to the Bible. He was the FATHER of the Hebrew nation due to his line of decent but he was a Chaldean by birth having been born in Ur a Chaldean city.

No…I think you have your times mixed up. He was born way before that time. Yes, he was born in Ur, but moved to Canaan and in doing so took on the citizenship of the land that would some day be called Israel. It would be like you moving from your home country, and knowing it was a forever move…you would apply for citizenship in your new country.

Abraham was an Aramean. Arabs invaded and subdued the region later. Note that there are those that contend Abraham is also the ancestor of Arabs who are said to to be descendants of Ishmael. Abraham was not a Hebrew. He is said to be born in Ur, modern day Iraq. His son Isaac fathered Jacob through whom the Children of Israel came about. It is not clear that they were Hebrews by the time Moses was given the Torah and they fled Egypt as no authentic records have been found in Egypt with Hebrew scripture from that time or that they evolved into Hebrew speaking people after the Kingdom of Judaea was established hundreds or thousands of years thereafter.
Ibrahim was Aramaic only his grand son Ya’qub ( Jacob ) became father of the Israelites.
Abraham wasn't Hebrew, he was Aramaic (or Kildanian in the Iraqi teminology). Hebrew became later.
Although Abraham was father of the Jewish nations, some question calling him a Jew since there were none when he was born.
Abraham was neither Jew, Muslim or Christian.
